description.narrative: Initiativet Inclusive Peace in Practice 2018-2022 av the Life & Peace Institute (LPI) fokuserar främst på att förändra lokala-till-globala engagemang kring globala fredsbyggande policies och normer, som till exempel Sustaining Peace Agenda, diskursen kring Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) och Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), och på att främja större grad av inkludering i relevanta policyprocesser. Det drivs av tron på att mer jämlikhet, deltagande och reciprocitet mellan globala beslutsfattare och lokala aktörer kan ändra normer över tid och därmed främja fredsbyggande policies som är mer anpassade till den dagliga verkligheten i konfliktdrabbade områden, och därmed mer effektiva och mer hållbara. Ett centralt fokus, givet LPI:s engagemang i typiskt svåråtkomna områden, är att påverka policies i stängda, osäkra och informella miljöer. LPI drar även på sina partnerskap, erfarenheter från landprogrammen och sina beprövade metoder som till exempel ledsagande-modellen och Participatory Action Research-ansatsen.

The Inclusive Peace in Practice initiative 2018-2022 by the Life & Peace Institute (LPI) focuses primarily on how to transform the local-to-global engagement on global peacebuilding policies and norms, such as the Sustaining Peace Agenda, the Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) discourse and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to promote inclusion in relevant policy processes. It is driven by the belief that greater equity, participation, and reciprocity between global decision-makers and local actors can shift norms over time and foster peacebuilding policy that is more directly connected to day-to-day lives in conflict affected areas, and thus more effective and more sustainable. A key focus, given LPI's engagement in typical 'hard-to-reach' areas, is policy-influencing in closed, insecure and informal environments. LPI furthermore draws on its partnerships, experiences from country programmes and its tested methodologies such as the accompaniment model and the Participatory Action Research approach.

The overall goal of the Inclusive Peace in Practice (IPIP) initiative is: Key actors within the peacebuilding ecosystem collaborate more effectively to develop and realise transformative global policy responses to specific conflicts
The Life and Peace Institute (LPI) stresses that the goal statement reflects the systems change that IPIP, along with others in the peacebuilding ecosystem, will work towards within the next 10 to 20 years. Key actors within the system are individuals and institutions whose efforts are relevant to specific conflict situations from local peace activists, civil society organisations, national authorities to international NGOs, think tanks and academic institutions, global networks and regional and global policy actors. Ultimately, it is LPI's vision that this change is meant to be felt positively by women, men, young women, young men, girls and boys living in violent conflict-affected contexts.

description.narrative:
The main narrative report for 2020 shows efforts made in the first year of the Inclusive Peace in Practice (IPIP) pilot programme. Despite the global pandemic, LPI managed to shift activities to virtual spaces and the report shows progress in all work streams.
Most notably for work stream one: Invited Spaces (where authorities invite people to participate in decision-making), LPI engaged in the 2020 United National Peacebuilding Architecture Review (UNPBAR) process by consulting a large number of communitybased peacebuilding practitioners, regional bodies such the AU and IGAD, INGOs and donor governments in their countries of operation. This resulted in an outcome report entitled "United Nations Peacebuilding Architecture in Practice: Perspectives from Local Peacebuilders in the Horn of Africa and Great Lakes Region (June 2020). It is worth noting that during this process, LPI also engaged the UN Peace Building Support Office as a learning partner in line with IPIP's intention of also preparing policy-makers in the global sphere to listen. During 2021, LPI has traced actual impact from this work in various ways. It is therefore likely that more concrete results of the process will be reported in subsequent reports.
In terms of work stream two: Claimed Spaces (where individuals and groups outside formal decision-making structures come together to generate their own space and set agendas for themselves), sometimes referred to as bottom-up policy engagement, for 2020 LPI focused on its Somalia programme and associated partners to identify a suitable policy process. In the end, reconciliation as a theme and the National Reconciliation Framework resonated across all communities as a focus to test approaches for inclusive peacebuilding.
IPIP's active focus on relationship building and peer-to-peer engagement has continued in 2020. The narrative report shows that LPI engages with a range of coalitions and working groups focused on global peacebuilding and support to local peace actors.
